members.name: Air Quality Monitoring Network (EPA SA)
members.description: The South Australian Environment Protection Authority monitors ambient air quality  in the metropolitan Adelaide and Spencer regions of South Australia. Pollutants measured include particles (PM10 and PM2.5), ozone (O3), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), carbon monoxide (CO) and sulfur dioxide (SO2). Please check individual site data for current parameters measured at each site. Data for each location is updated hourly.

members.name: Air Quality Monitoring Network (NSW)
members.description: Air quality monitoring sites are set up in Sydney and several regional areas of NSW. Particles (PM10, PM2.5, TSP), sulfur dioxide (SO2), carbon monoxide (CO), ozone (O3), nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and visibility are reported on an hourly basis. Please check individual site data for current parameters measured at each site.

members.name: Air Quality Monitoring Network (NT EPA)
members.description: Air quality monitoring stations are set up at three sites (Palmerston, Winnellie and Stokes Hill) in the Darwin Region. Concentrations of Particles (PM10 & PM2.5), sulfur dioxide (SO2), carbon monoxide (CO), ozone (O3) and oxides of nitrogen (NO2, NO & NOx) in air are reported at each site as well as various meteorological parameters, and updated hourly. Please check individual site data for current parameters measured at each site. Air Quality Index (AQI) values are also calculated using data collected at each air quality monitoring site.

members.name: Air Quality Monitoring Network (TAS)
members.description: EPA Tasmania operates an air quality monitoring network of three main stations and 32 smaller stations across the state. The main stations measure PM10 and PM2.5 using NEPM compliant equipment.  The 32 smaller stations use locally calibrated optical-scatter instruments for PM2.5 and PM10 measurement. Optical-scatter instruments are also operated at the three main stations. Real-time PM2.5 and PM10, and meteorological data are reported to the EPAs public webpages every 10-minutes.

members.name: AusPollen Aerobiology Collaboration Monitoring Network
members.description:
The network monitors  airborne pollen and spore concentrations using  Burkard volumetric continuous flow pollen and spore traps to sample and manually count pollen and fungal spore concentrations daily during the peak grass pollen period.
See the AusPollen vocabulary in the Research Vocabulary Australia website at https://vocabs.ardc.edu.au/viewById/300

members.name: Wind Profiler
members.description: The BoM monitors the vertical wind profile up to an altitude of 8 km (Boundary layer) to 16 km (stratospheric) above ground level at sites across Australia. The data are processed by EUMETNET in Europe and then made available to the global meteorological community. The data is also used by the BoM Numerical Weather Prediction models.

members.name: Land (6)
Acoustic pressure (GA)
members.description: Geoscience Australia is currently responsible for the operation and maintenance of nine of Australia's seismo-acoustic IMS facilities (six seismic stations, two infrasound stations and one hydroacoustic station). Additionally, Geoscience Australia is in the process of building a further two infrasound stations to complete Australia's seismo-acoustic IMS network. Construction of these stations is expected to be completed within the next three to four years.

members.name: Australian ground cover reference sites database 2014 (ABARES)
members.description: The ground cover reference sites database contains the data collected from a national network of ground cover reference sites. This network was established to validate a remotely sensed product describing green or photosynthetic vegetation, non-green or non-photosynthetic vegetation and bare soil. The data includes site descriptions and associated field measurements of fractional coverhttp://www.agriculture.gov.au/abares/aclump/land-cover/ground-cover-monitoring-for-australia

members.description: Geoscience Australia maintains a national network of geomagnetic observatories which forms part of a global observatory network. Data measured at these observatories show how the Earth's magnetic field changes in the Australian region due to processes taking place beneath the Earth's surface, in the upper atmosphere and in the Earth-Sun space environment.

members.name: Seismic (GA)
members.description: Geoscience Australia monitors seismic data from more than 60 stations on the Australian National Seismograph Network and in excess of 300 stations worldwide in near real-time, 24 hours a day, seven days a week. Most of the 40 samples per second data are delivered within 30 seconds of being recorded at the seismometer to Geoscience Australia's central processing facility in Canberra through various digital satellite and broadband communication systems.

members.name: Ocean (11)
Acidification Moorings (IMOS)
members.description: The Acidification Moorings sub-facility is responsible for building an ocean carbon and acidification monitoring network for Australian waters. The acidification moorings provide measurements of CO2 and related parameters. Acidification moorings have been co-located at three National Reference Stations; Yongala in Queensland (was moved to Heron Island after cycline damage), off Maria Island, Tasmania, and off the west coast of Kangaroo Island, South Australia.

members.name: Acoustic Observatories (IMOS)
members.description: The passive acoustic observatories record sound emitted by natural processes in the ocean, underwater noise sources of biological origin, such as marine mammals, crustaceans or fish, plus man-made noise sources. Sites currently sampled are located: off the central NSW coast; south of Portland, Victoria; west of Kangaroo island; and west of Perth in the Perth Canyon. In addition to this, two sites were sampled from 2012-2015, these sites were located off the north coast of Western Australia.

members.name: Calibration/Validation Network (IMOS)
members.description: The Australian calibration site includes two comparison points where in situ data is compared against the altimeter, Bass Strait and Storm Bay (now discontinued). These two locations both lie on descending (N -> S) pass 088 of the satellite altimeter, and thus share similar satellite orbit characteristics. The use of these two sites allows detailed investigation into the accuracy of the altimeter over two different wave climates.

members.name: Coastal Tsunami Gauges (BoM)
members.description: The Australian Tsunami Warning System is a national collaboration between the Australian Bureau of Meteorology (Bureau), Geoscience Australia (GA) and the Department of Home Affairs (Home Affairs) which provides a comprehensive tsunami warning system delivering timely and effective tsunami warnings to the Australian population. It is also a key element of the Indian Ocean Tsunami Warning and Mitigation System, and contributes to the facilitation of tsunami warnings for the South West Pacific.

members.name: National Reference Stations (IMOS)
members.description: The National Reference Stations collect observations of both physical and biogeochemical variables. Observations are sensor-based and supplemented by vessel-based biogeochemical sampling (and laboratory analysis). As the resources required to sustain physical and biogeochemical observations over the long term are significant, the NRS Network consists of the minimum number of sites necessary to provide a national multi-decadal baseline.

Caution must be observed for those months with large gaps.

members.name: Wireless Sensor Networks (IMOS)
members.description: The Wireless Sensor Networks refer to an array of small, wirelessly interconnected sensors that collectively stream data to a central data aggregation point. Wireless Sensor Networks were initially deployed at seven sites along the Great Barrier Reef, from Heron Island in the south to Lizard Island in the north. In 2014 there was a consolidation of sites, currently there are five sites in operation across the Great Barrier Reef.

members.name: Other (9)
EIExplorer_Decommissioned_231118_(BoM) all sites file 1 of 3
members.description:
The Environmental Information (EI) Explorer sites are water resource and meteorological monitoring sites owned and managed by over 90 organisations across Australia.  Last updated in 2009, data for water resource stations includes the quality and quantity of water in surface water features, particularly rivers and water storages, and meteorological data includes rainfall, evaporation, humidity, and temperature.  There are more than 15,000 surface water sites and more than 22,000 meteorological sites.  Site information includes that supplied to the Bureau of Meteorology, under the Water Regulations 2008, by water management authorities in each State and Territory.

This file is one of three that together cover all the EI Explorer monitoring sites.

There are more than 15,000 surface water sites and more than 22,000 meteorological sites.  Site information includes that supplied to the Bureau of Meteorology, under the Water Regulations 2008, by water management authorities in each State and Territory.

This file contains all the EI Explorer surface water monitoring sites.

members.name: Water (11)
Hydrologic Reference Stations (BoM)
members.description:
The Hydrologic Reference Stations identifies Australian streamflow trends and detects long-term variability and change in streamflow.
You can search the national network of 467 stations from a single website and view or download comprehensive streamflow information for a specific station. Using the online tool you can select a station, explore and display streamflow data as an annual, seasonal, monthly or daily time series. You can also explore trends in streamflow using the trend explorer for the Hydrologic Reference Stations.
The Hydrologic Reference Stations are well-maintained river gauges of long, high quality streamflow records managed by Australian and State water agencies. The stations can be used to estimate trends in long-term and seasonal water availability from climate variability and change.
Spread across contrasting hydro-climatic regions, the network includes unregulated streamflow stations in catchments with minimal effects of water resource development and land use change. The main objective of the Hydrologic Reference Stations is to allow for detection and attribution of long-term streamflow variability and change.  
The Hydrologic Reference Stations is delivered by the Bureau of Meteorology, which has responsibility for compiling and delivering Australia's water information, as part of the Australian Government's $450 million Improving Water Information Program.

members.name: Water Data Online - Electrical Conductivity @ 25C (BoM)
members.description: The Bureau of Meteorology receives water data measured at stations around Australia from organisations named in the Water Regulations (2008). Approximately 6500 measurement stations across Australia are currently available in Water Data Online. Stations in the 'Water Data Online (BoM)' and the 'Water Regulations Data (BoM)' networks, in the NEII Data Services Conformant section of the NEII viewer, are essentially the same. Stations are only released to the 'Water Data Online (BoM)' networks once high level checks have been completed. More stations may be available on the 'Water Regulations Data (BoM)' network as it updates automatically using web services and includes all stations available in the Bureau's Australian Water Resources Information System (AWRIS). Parameters currently available in Water Data Online are: Watercourse Level (Water Regulations subcategory 1a) Watercourse Discharge (Water Regulations subcategory 1b) Storage Level (Water Regulations subcategory 3a) Storage Volume (Water Regulations subcategory 3b) Electrical Conductivity of surface water @ 25C (Water Regulations subcategory 9a) Turbidity of surface water (Water Regulations subcategory 9d) pH of surface water (Water Regulations subcategory 9g) Temperature of surface water (Water Regulations subcategory 9h) The number of water information categories and water monitoring stations presented will increase over time. The data is available at Water Data Online. Web Services may be used access the water data. A Sensor Observation Service standard version 2 (SOS2) has been implemented. The service returns data in WaterML2 format. Information on how to use the service is available in the Guide to Sensor Observation Services (SOS2) for Water Data Online v1.0.1.pdf.

catalog.description: Abstract: The National Environmental Monitoring Sites Register (NEMSR) provides a consolidated view of Australia's environmental monitoring sites. It brings together a diverse range of networks across environmental domains. Users can select one or more networks and display them through data viewer. Clicking on a site shows its location, site metadata and provides a link to the data itself. NEMSR can also be accessed programmatically through the endpoints listed here. Custodian: Bureau of Meteorology Further information: www.neii.gov.au/nemsr
